reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s “scale-tipping” objection to bounded joint-aggregation views, which is a supporting (not core) reason the authors give for thinking the only easygoing bounded views are implausible; so centrality is moderate-low (~0.25). However, it largely misses the paper’s point: the objection is about the plausibility/continuity and moral significance of the value function (tiny balance changes flipping the universe from near-worst to near-best), not about whether agents could adopt a stable policy (“keep the net positive”). Pointing out a policy response doesn’t dissolve the alleged implausibility, and it arguably concedes a kind of threshold-directed ‘fussiness’ anyway. So it only weakly undermines the attacked claim (low strength). The critique is partly correct that a scale-tipping view would induce strong incentives to secure a positive margin, but its suggestion that this makes the objection non-problematic is not well-supported and conflates strategic implications with evaluative pathology (moderate correctness). It’s mostly understandable but uses an undefined term (“Equilibrium shift”) and leaves key notions (what ‘directed’ vs ‘fussy’ means) under-specified (clarity ~0.75). Little dead weight, and it stays on one issue.
title: Scale-tipping views rationally direct civilizations toward stable positive margins
